facts.text: Appellant, resident of Simla, is a forest contractor who took forests on lease in 1942-43 in erstwhile Indian State of Jubbal for exploitation. Work of felling trees and extraction of timber continued up to 1945-46.
No profit or loss account prepared for each of the four years separately; consolidated balance-sheet and profit and loss account drawn up for all four years.
In appellant's Income-tax returns, income from forest business calculated and shown by applying 10% net on sales made in relevant years.

In assessment proceedings for 1943-44, appellant sold timber in Jubbal in 1942-43 to Sukh Dial Jagat Ram (firm in Abdullapore, Ambala) for Rs. 1,91,000. No part of sale proceeds received during 1942-43.

Income-tax Officer by order dated 2nd February 1948 held profit on sale of Rs. 1,91,000 in 1942-43 as Rs. 20,967; income considered only for rate fixing due to no receipt; profits for 1943-44, 1944-45, 1945-46 also determined.
On appeal, Appellate Assistant Commissioner allowed certain expenses, reducing total income; profit for 1942-43 reduced from Rs. 20,967.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal further reduced profits by Rs. 5,000 allowance; final profit for 1942-43 ascertained as Rs. 18,758.

In assessment for 1944-45, out of Rs. 1,91,000: Rs. 1,25,000 received in cash in Jubbal; Rs. 29,000 received in cash by appellant in British India; Rs. 3,000 paid in cash in British India to appellant's creditor Sita Ram.

Income-tax Officer held Rs. 29,000 + Rs. 3,000 = Rs. 32,000 received in 1943-44 included entire profit accrued in 1942-43, assessable under section 4(1)(b)(iii) as income accrued outside British India but brought in.
Appellate Assistant Commissioner upheld Income-tax Officer.
Income-tax Appellate Tribunal upheld, holding payments tantamount to constructive remittances of profits.
Appellant applied to Tribunal under section 66(1) for reference on five questions (one withdrawn); Tribunal dismissed on 7th August 1950.
Appellant applied to High Court of Punjab under section 66(2); High Court dismissed on 25th June 1953 holding no question of law arose from Tribunal order dated 4th November 1949.
Special leave to appeal granted by Supreme Court on 18th May 1954.

legal_issues.text: Whether there is material for finding that assessee instructed debtor in Jubbal to pay Rs. 32,000 in British India instead of direct remittance.
Whether receipt of Rs. 32,000 correctly held to be constructive remittance from Jubbal to British India.
Whether correctly held that assessee remitted entire profits of 1942-43 in Rs. 32,000.
Whether evidence supports finding that Rs. 32,000 includes entire profits earned in Jubbal in 1942-43.

petitioner_arguments.text: At dates of receipt in British India, no profit made as timber sold in 1942-43 but no payment received; in 1943-44 Rs. 1,57,000 received below total outlay; profit only after recouping entire outlay.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla

petitioner_arguments.text: No remittance by appellant from Jubbal; Rs. 3,000 paid to creditor not remittance.
Not whole profit of Rs. 18,758 remitted, but proportionate part attributable to Rs. 32,000.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal

respondent_arguments.text: Rs. 32,000 received in British India tantamount to constructive remittances of profits from Jubbal.
Payments made according to appellant's instructions; presumption that remittances are profits unless contrary shown.

court_reasoning.text: Profit accrues on sale in 1942-43, ascertained as Rs. 18,758 finally; presumption that remittances from foreign business are profits unless contrary shown.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Appellant cannot go behind final profit finding; failed to discharge onus.

court_reasoning.text: No force in contention no profit until outlay recouped; appellant could have remitted anticipated profit; Bhagwandas case inapplicable as different facts.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Events support view of profit remittance.

court_reasoning.text: Rs. 3,000 payment to creditor and Rs. 29,000 direct indicate instructions by appellant; purchaser acted as agent; constructive remittance.
Turner Morrison inapplicable; presumption applies as equivalent to remittance via agent.
No real or substantial question of law arises from Tribunal order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: High Court justified in dismissing s.66(2) application.

holdings.text: Profit accrues on sale; remittances from foreign business presumed profits unless rebutted.
Payments in British India per instructions amount to constructive remittances of profits.
No question of law arises warranting reference under s.66(2).

precedents_cited.case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, Burma v. Bhagwandas Bagla
precedents_cited.relevance: Different facts: remittances were return of initial outlay for goods sent abroad; no profit until outlay recovered.

precedents_cited.case_name: Turner Morrison Co. Ltd. v. Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal
precedents_cited.relevance: Inapplicable as presumption of profit in remittances via agent applies here.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Income-tax Act, 1922
statutes_cited.relevance: s.4(1)(b)(iii) for taxing income accrued outside but brought into British India; s.66 for reference to High Court.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeal, upholding High Court dismissal of s.66(2) application; no question of law arose; Rs.32,000 treated as constructive remittance including entire profit of Rs.18,758 from 1942-43 sale.
outcome.costs: With costs (as per High Court order)

key_quotes.text: There can be no getting away from the fact that profit accrues or arises on the sale, which in this case took place in 1942-43.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on accrual of profit.

key_quotes.text: The presumption, according to the cases referred to in the judgment under appeal, will be that the remittances of money from foreign business to British India must be of profits, unless the contrary were shown by the appellant.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: No real or substantial question of law arises from the order of the Appellate Tribunal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
